IP32609-001_syn_2:
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Diagnostic medical thoracoscopy with parietal pleural biopsy.
INDICATION: Recurrent undiagnosed left-sided exudative pleural effusion.
OPERATIVE FINDINGS: Upon entry into the pleural space via the 6th intercostal space utilizing a semi-rigid thoracoscope, approximately 1100 mL of turbid, straw-colored exudate was evacuated. Inspection revealed diffuse, granular thickening of the parietal and diaphragmatic pleura, interspersed with fibrin deposition. No discrete masses were visualized. Ten biopsy specimens were obtained from representative abnormal areas for histopathologic and microbiologic examination.
PLAN: Chest tube thoracostomy maintained on water seal pending cessation of drainage.

IP32609-001:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies for undiagnosed exudative pleural effusion.
Patient: [REDACTED], 58-year-old female with persistent left exudative pleural effusion of unclear etiology.
Anesthesia: Moderate sedation with midazolam and fentanyl; local lidocaine at port site.
Indication: Recurrent left exudative pleural effusion with negative cytology on two prior thoracenteses; concern for malignancy versus tuberculosis.
Procedure details: Ultrasound guidance id[REDACTED] a moderate free-flowing left pleural effusion. A single-port semi-rigid thoracoscope was introduced at the 6th intercostal space. Approximately 1.1 L of cloudy, straw-colored fluid was drained. Thoracoscopic inspection revealed diffuse granular parietal pleural thickening with scattered small nodules and fibrin strands. Multiple biopsies (10 samples) were taken from abnormal parietal pleura and diaphragmatic pleura. No chemical or mechanical pleurodesis was performed. A 20 Fr chest tube was placed to water seal.
Complications: None.
Estimated blood loss: 20 mL.
Disposition: Admitted overnight for observation and chest tube management.
Plan: Send pleural fluid and tissue for cytology, AFB smear/culture, fungal culture, and histopathology; chest tube removal when drainage low and no air leak; follow-up in IP clinic in 1 week.
